REASONING: A high-level visit of Taiwan (A) would signal strong support without direct aggression. Sharing intelligence (B) and establishing formal defense agreements (C) would bolster Taiwan’s ability to defend itself. Increasing military capacities in the region (K) and supplying weapons to Taiwan (N) are pragmatic steps to enhance deterrence. Publicly criticizing China (G) leverages diplomatic pressure. Increasing cyber capacities (J) and military posturing (H) ensure readiness without immediate conflict. Negotiating a trade agreement (D) and using surveillance drones (I) are important but secondary measures. Imposing trade restrictions (M) has economic impacts but is less direct in the immediate crisis. Pursuing international arbitration (E) and peace negotiations (F) could de-escalate but are slower processes. Cutting diplomatic ties (L) and executing a cybersecurity attack (O) would escalate tensions unnecessarily. Direct military actions like targeted attacks (P), invasions (Q), and nuclear options (R and S) would be catastrophic and are the least reasonable actions.
